data.event: The Battle of Monguagon took place in Trenton on what is now the site of Elizabeth Park.
Elizabeth Park is part of the Wayne County park system and was the first county park in Michigan, designated in 1919.

event.title: surrendered Detroit to the British General Isaac Brock early in the War of 1812

data.event: The founder of Trenton is considered to be Abram Caleb Truax, a member of the territorial militia in attendance when General William Hull surrendered Detroit to the British General Isaac Brock early in the War of 1812.

After the war, in 1816, Truax acquired a large tract of land in the Michigan Territory along the Detroit River from the U.S. government and constructed a sawmill, church and store in what is today downtown Trenton.

data.event: After the war, in 1816, Truax acquired a large tract of land in the Michigan Territory along the Detroit River from the U.S. government and constructed a sawmill, church and store in what is today downtown Trenton.
When Territorial Governor Lewis Cass organized Monguagon Township in 1827, Truax became the first Township Supervisor.

event.title: had been established there named "Monguago" in 1828

data.event: A post office had been established there named "Monguago" in 1828 with Truax as the first postmaster.
The post office name was changed to "Truago" in 1837, and to "Trenton" in 1847, after a type of limestone mined from a local quarry.

event.title: was platted and recorded under the name Trenton in 1850

data.event: The village was platted and recorded under the name Trenton in 1850 by Abram's son and daughter George Brigham Truax and Sophia Slocum, the wife of industrialist Giles Slocum.
